metadata.name: Renamed PAExec Execution
metadata.comment: Detects execution of renamed version of PAExec. Often used by attackers

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (lower(activity_id) = lower('1') AND lower(device.desc) = lower('paexec application') AND lower(process.file.name) = lower('paexec.exe') AND contains(lower(metadata.product.name), lower('paexec')) AND (contains(lower(process.file.hashes.value), lower('imphash=11d40a7b7876288f919ab819cc2d9802')) OR contains(lower(process.file.hashes.value), lower('imphash=6444f8a34e99b8f7d9647de66aabe516')) OR contains(lower(process.file.hashes.value), lower('imphash=dfd6aa3f7b2b1035b76b718f1ddc689f')) OR contains(lower(process.file.hashes.value), lower('imphash=1a6cca4d5460b1710a12dea39e4a592c'))) AND NOT (endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\paexec.exe')) AND startswith(lower(process.name), lower('c:\\windows\\paexec-'))))

output.summary: Detects execution of renamed version of PAExec. Often used by attackers

metadata.objective: False positives: 1. Weird admins that rename their tools 2. Software companies that bundle PAExec with their software and rename it, so that it is less embarrassing 3. When executed with the "-s" flag. PAExec will copy itself to the "C:\Windows\" directory with a different name. Usually like this "PAExec-[XXXXX]-[ComputerName]" References: https://www.poweradmin.com/paexec/, https://summit.fireeye.com/content/dam/fireeye-www/summit/cds-2018/presentations/cds18-technical-s05-att&cking-fin7.pdf
